description.b: In this part of the tutorial you are going to create a new, empty scenario file - then populate it with sample data. The scenario will describe a frigate looking for a fishing vessel

item.title: Select location for new scenario
item.description: Some thinking first. Have a look in your navigator view, and decide on a location for your new scenario file. It isn't all that tidy to put it into the existing AssetData sample data folder, so you could create a new folder in the root of your project (by right-clicking on the root folder and selecting 'New Folder'. The new folder could be called 'trials', for example.

item.title: Create empty scenario file
item.description:
Now that you know where to put the new scenario, right click on the parent folder and select New \ Other.... From the tree of available wizards, select 'XML File' from the 'XML' folder. Now press 'Next'. On the next page of the wizard, provide a filename for the new scenario - how about trial1.asset.
Note: ASSET runs more smoothly if you name scenarios with the .asset suffix.
On the next page, select Create XML file from an XML template, then indicate that you want a new Asset Scenario. The file will then open.open.

item.title: Admire the editor
item.description:
Your new scenario will probably open in Source view. This is ok for geeks, but you may find it easier to use the tree oriented view. Switch to this by clicking on the Design tab at the foot of the editor pane.
Now your in the graphic view, experiment with expanding the Scenario.
By the way, if you look at ASSET's Outline view (or click the arrow below) you'll see an outline view of the current sceanrio.
ASSET's Properties view is also useful when working with scenario files. Open the properties view by selecting Window/Show View/Properties. Now, you are able to edit the attributes for any element selected in the editor view.

item.title: Edit scenario properties
item.description:
Youve got big dreams? You want fame? Well, fame costs. And right here is where you start paying in sweat.
Well, not quite, but you do have to start typing now. So, open the Scenario element, and give the scenario a name 'Cheat sheet scenario'. If you switch to the properties view you'll see the other attributes needed: Created and StartTime. ASSET expects dates in the ISO 8601 date standard: 2010-01-12T12:13:14Z. Put in today's date as the created attribute, and any old date as the StartTime attribute.
Next, specify how far in time the scenario should step forward (StepTime). Have a go at five minutes: Minutes are the Unit and 5 is the Value.
Read more about the attributes of the scenario element using the help link near this text.

item.title: Specify Environment
item.description:
Now we have to give the scenario an environment. Do this by right-clicking on the Scenario and selecting Add child / Environment. Also, give it a name - how about Atlantic Summer. Play with the sea state and atmospheric attenuation if you wish.
You can learn more about the role of the attributes in the attached help link.

item.title: Add simple participant
item.description: Next, we have to put something into the scenario. Right-click on Participants and select Surface. If you open up the new participant, you'll see that the compulsary elements have already been included. Now, give the vessel a name, Fisher One should do.

item.title: Tidy the participant
item.description:
Now it's tome to flesh out a little more of the fishing vessel. Start off with the category - indicate that it's a FISHING_VESSEL of the GREEN force and it travels in the SURFACE environment.
We'll leave the sensor fit empty, but we should give it an initial status. Set the Course to 30, then Fuel to 100. Now set the location to Lat of 50 and Long of -8. Lastly, specify a Speed of 6 Knots.

item.title: Specify the movement characteristics
item.description: Next up we have to inform ASSET regarding how the fishing vessel performs in the SurfaceMovementCharacteristics. Enter the following data = Name: 9m Fisherman, FuelUsageRate 0.0001, MinSpeed0 Kts, MaxSpeed12 Kts, AccelerationRate 1 kt/sec, DeceleratonRate 1 kt/sec, TurningCircle 400 metres.

item.title: Provide participant behaviour
item.description: Next, we're going to indicate what the fishing vessel is up to. We're going to make it travel to a fishing ground, and then wander around it. Do this by right-clicking on the Surface element and selecting Sequence from the Add-Child sub-menu. See the help link (right) for more on the Sequence behaviour. Name this sequence element "Southern Trawl". Also, mark the Sequence behaviour as being 'Active' (by setting IsActive true from the properties window).

item.title: Next comes the transit.
item.description: Right-click on the Sequence element and select Transit from the Add-child drop-down. Name this transit as 'Travel to fishing grounds', set Looping to false, and fill in the WorldPath's location as Lat 50.4 and Long -8.8. Also specify the transit speed as 9 knots.

item.title: Gone fishing
item.description: Right-click on the Transit element and select Wander from the Add After drop-down. Fill in the Wander element by specifying the name as 'morning trawl', a speed of 9 knots, the location to 50.4, -8.8. Specify the height as zero, and set the range to 12 nautical miles.

item.title: Now for the warship
item.description: Next we're going to add a warship to the scenario. Right-click on Participants and select Surface from 'add child'. We'll name this T23. Next, set its category as a Blue, Surface, Frigate.

item.title: Gvie it a sensor
item.description: To keep things simple we're going to give the Frigate a very simple cookie-cutter sensor, that blindly checks the range to the target against its detection range attribute. So, right-click on SensorFit and add a PlainCookieSensor. Set the detection range of the sensor to 3 nautical miles.

item.title: Locate the warship
item.description: Next, we've got to tell the warship where it is. Go into the Status element and set the location to 50 degs of latitude, and -10 degs of longitude.

item.title: Specify the warship movement details
item.description: Next, expand the SurfaceMovementCharacteristics item to specify how the warship moves. I've been finding this easier to do in the Source view for the editor - switch by clicking on the tab at the foot of the editor page. Give the Frigate a max speed of 12 kts, accel and decel rates of 1 kt per second, and a turning circle of 300m.

item.title: Direct the warship
item.description:
To create the placeholder for the Warship's behaviour, right-click on it and add a Waterfall behaviour.
We're going to have the warship wandering around the same body of water as the fisherman, so go into the Source view and copy the Wander behaviour, and paste it into the Waterfall of the Frigate. Back in the Design view, change the name of this Wander behaviour to Count fishing vessels.

item.title: Done
item.description: And we're done. We've got a valid scenario that describes what our fishing vessel is up to.
